comments:
In the course, students learn to use computer-based tools to gather data, model, and solve common quantitative problems that arise frequently in business settings. Key topics include constrained optimization, process modeling, operational analysis, and decision theory. Students also learn to construct and re-use macros to automate tedious data gathering and model execution. The goal of the course is to provide a set of foundation skills and an overview of problems and techniques that characterize the disciplines that comprise Operations and Information Management. 

Overall, students thought that skills learned in the course were \\\"important,\\\" \\\"applicable,\\\" and \\\"relevant\\\" to their work in the future. One student said that the course gave her a \\\"novel way\\\" to look at operations and information management. Nonetheless, most students commented that OPIM101 was a challenging course that demanded a lot of work and covered a vast amount of material in a semester. In addition, students hope that the organization can be improved in the future, so that more time is spent teaching VBA programming in lecture. Several students thought that the pace was too fast, which disadvantaged students with no prior experience with programming. 

Professor Lee, who taught the programming section of the course, is \\\"well-spoken,\\\" \\\"engaging,\\\" and \\\"articulate,\\\" according to several students. Professor Lee is a great lecturer who manages to cover even a large amount of material well and does an excellent job trying to communicate a difficult subject matter. Meanwhile, some students found Professor Lee \"unapproachable\" and thought that the course could be taught more effectively. 

Most of the students in this course were Wharton freshmen. Overall, students describe the course as \"challenging\" and \"a substantial time commitment.\" Students received six homework assignments, in addition to completing exercises in recitation. To reinforce course material, mentoring sessions were offered outside of class. Students commented that the course was very \"beneficial,\" but that it would be more effective if the course were structured differently.

In the course, students learn to use computer-based tools to gather data, model, and solve common quantitative problems that arise frequently in business settings. Key topics include constrained optimization, process modeling, operational analysis, and decision theory. Students also learn to construct and re-use macros to automate tedious data gathering and model execution. The goal of the course is to provide a set of foundation skills and an overview of problems and techniques that characterize the disciplines that comprise Operations and Information Management. 

Overall, students thought that skills learned in the course were \"important,\" \"applicable,\" and \"relevant\" to their work in the future. One student said that the course gave her a \"novel way\" to look at operations and information management. Nonetheless, most students commented that OPIM101 was a challenging course that demanded a lot of work and covered a vast amount of material in a semester. In addition, students hope that the organization can be improved in the future, so that more time is spent teaching VBA programming in lecture. Several students thought that the pace was too fast, which disadvantaged students with no prior experience with programming. 

Students describe Professor Cachon, who taught the operations portion of the course, as \"friendly\" and a \"great public speaker\" who made students think about operations. Professor Cachon knew the course material well and was always excited to teach. Students found Professor Cachon \"relatable\" and thought he \"made the course material engaging.\"

To reinforce course material, mentoring sessions were offered outside of class. Students commented that the course was very \"beneficial,\" but that it would be more effective if the course were structured differently.

OPIM 101 intends to provide a foundation in both computers and modeling for use in subsequent courses at Wharton as well as for the student’s professional career. Topics include budgeting, analytical modeling, sensitivity analysis, database management, inventory control analysis, decision analysis, optimization, neural networks, genetic algorithms, and simulation. Cases require model solutions using Microsoft Excel and an executive slide presentation of results and management recommendations using Microsoft Excel or PowerPoint.
Students commented that this course was not very well organized. The computer skills needed for this class were said to not be taught and assumed to be known. Most specifically, it was claimed that the visual basic (VBA) material felt rushed and was not taught well.
Students claimed that “Professor Hill moved through concepts far too quickly but was very good at offering assistance.” It was also said that she “did a great job with her presentations at the beginning of each recitation.” Students said that getting attention from the professors, especially during recitation and even during mentoring sections and office hours, was difficult because there were too many students.

In terms of target audience, this class being a requirement for Wharton undergraduates was said to be “frustrating especially for students who have no previous programming experience.” However, the course descriptions states that no prior background in either computers or operations and information management is expected.
